Question 1.Question: In the democracy, sovereign authority is exercised by the
Question 1.Explanation: In a democracy, sovereignty belongs to the people. During elections, the sovereignty and legitimacy is conferred on their elected candidates who represent them in government provided the election is free and fair.

Options.Value: School
Family
Peer group
Pressure group

Question 2.Question: The agent through which the state undertakes political socialization is the
Question 2.Explanation: Pressure groups are groups which influence the activities of the government in various ways without necessarily taking control of government.

Parliamentarism
Unitarism
Federalism

Question 3.Question: Unicameral legislature is a common feature of
Question 3.Explanation: A unicameral legislature is a common feature of a unitary state which usually has a small size and limited diversity in customs and ethnic groups. Thus each ethnic group can be properly represented even with one legislative chamber.

Options.Value: Determine a fixed term of office for the judges
Dismiss any judge who has breached the judicial code of conduct
Enable the judges to try and decide cases without bias
Determine a fixed salary for judge

Question 4.Question: Independence of the judiciary is pertinent because it accords the judiciary the power to
Question 4.Explanation: An independent judiciary is one whose remuneration is guaranteed; appointment and removal is based on merit; one which is not moved by personal gain or public opinion; and one which is free from the influence of the other arms of government.

Options.Value: Without devolution
With devolution
With residual functions
Without residual functions

Question 5.Question: In a unitary system of government, power is concentrated at the centre
Question 5.Explanation: Devolution is the transfer of powers from a central government to its component unit. In a unitary system of government, power is concentrated only in the central government.

Options.Value: Senatorial district
Parliamentary constituency
Nation-state
Region

Question 6.Explanation: Each member state in a legislation of a constituency represent a region.

Question 7.Question: In a constitutional monarchy, the authority to remove the head of state is exercised by the
Question 7.Explanation: In a constitutional monarchy the monarch rules in line with the provision of the laws of the land. The legislature then acts as checks on his powers.

Options.Value: The entire cabinet
An individual minister
The entire parliament
The prime minister

Question 8.Question: In a parliamentary system of government, a vote of no confidence leads to the resignation of
Question 8.Explanation: The prime minister and his cabinet forms the executive. Due to the principle of collective responsibility, a fault found in a member of the cabinet will have to be blamed on the whole cabinet.

Options.Value: Executive order
Executive review
Exercise of veto
Legislative order

Question 9.Question: In a presidential system of government, the president checks the legislature through
Question 9.Explanation: The veto power of the president is exercised through his assent to bills. After a bill has been passed by the legislative, it is sent to the president for assent. However, if the president feels that the bill is unfavorable on any ground, he can withhold his assent.

Options.Value: Capital
Agriculture
Slavery
Trade

Question 10.Question: The economic basis of feudalism is
Question 10.Explanation: Feudalism is a form of government based on the ownership of land. Agriculture is the main occupation due to the importance associated with land. The lords are land owners while serfs are made to work on the land as servants.

Options.Value: Communism
Capitalism
Socialism
Fascism

Question 11.Question: The creation of a classless society is the ultimate aim of
Question 11.Explanation: Communism is a political and economic growth in which the society is based on the common possession of the means of production and the equal distribution of goods, lands and resources.

Question 12.Question: One of the sources of a constitution is
Question 12.Explanation: The source of a constitution are written documents, organic laws (also known as statutory law), judicial decisions, principle of philosophers, constitutional customs and conventions and lastly, experience of the people.

Options.Value: Rationality of human beings
Equality of human beings
Love for social justice
Supremacy of the constitution

Question 13.Question: The fundamental assumption on which the idea of the rule of law is based is
Question 13.Explanation: The most important element of the rule of law is supremacy of the constitution. It is only when the supremacy of the fundamental law of the land is recognized and respected that the rule of law can flourish in a country.

Options.Value: John Locke
Baron de Montesquieu
Thomas Hobbes
Niccolo Machiavelli

Question 14.Question: The principle of separation of powers was made popular by
Question 14.Explanation: The principle of separation of powers was propounded by John Locke but it was made popular and modernized through the writings of Baron de Montesquieu.

Question 15.Question: Delegated legislation refers to the laws made by
Question 15.Explanation: Delegated legislations are laws made by administrative authorities, public authorities or agencies. These are not legislative but executive bodies.

Question 16.Question: Laws made by state governments are known as
Question 16.Explanation: Edicts are laws made by the state government during a military regime; bye laws are made by local governments; decrees are laws made by the Federal military government while acts are made by the Federal Democratic government.

Movement

Question 17.Question: The law of libel limits a citizen’s right to freedom of
Question 17.Explanation: The right to freedom of expression allows a person to communicate ideas, opinions and information of all kinds. However, this right doesn’t give any person the right to write anything or make a pictorial representation which unjustly seeks to damage someone’s reputation, otherwise known as defamation.

Question 18.Question: The first franchise in the history of the democratic process is
Question 18.Explanation: The Clifford constitution of 1922 established male suffrage. Only male adults with residential qualification of one year and a gross income of 100 pounds per annum were allowed to vote.

Question 19.Question: An interest group that admits members and conducts its affairs according to stated rules is described as
Question 19.Explanation: Professional interest/pressure groups set ground rules for the profession, regulate practices and promote standards of conduct. They also lobby the government on issues related to their profession.

Question 20.Explanation: Communication and information is an important aspect in forming public opinion. The mass media controls these and the government can determine people’s opinion by exploring the mass media.

Question 21.Explanation: In the civil service, positions are hierarchical. In a descending order of importance, the civil service has the administrative staff, executive staff, professional staff, clerical staff, and the auxiliary staff.

Question 22.Explanation: The Oyo Empire was the central government while the provinces were the subordinate units headed by the Oba or Baale.

Question 23.Question: The major motivation for British colonization of Nigeria was to
Question 23.Explanation: The Britain colonized Nigeria in order to get raw materials and markets, as well as improve Britain’s development in science and technology.

Question 24.Question: The Native Authority system was most effective and successful in
Question 24.Explanation: The use of native Authority was successful in Northern Nigeria because there was centralization of power and total obedience to the constituted authority. Thus, it was easy for the British to rule the people of the North indirectly through their native leaders.

Question 25.Question: The process of nationalism was accelerated by
Question 25.Explanation: The Atlantic Charter was signed by Britain after the World War II. The provision of the Charter emphasized right to self – determination by all the people around the world (a contrast to colonialism) and this fuelled the nationalists’ fight for independence.

Question 28.Explanation: The second republic constitution of 1979 adopted an executive presidential system, established a bi-cameral legislature, embraced the principle of federation character and provided for run-off elections, among others.

Question 29.Question: The two chambers of elected national representatives in Nigeria are called
Question 29.Explanation: The National Assembly is the Federal legislative body in Nigeria and it is composed of two chambers. Question 31.Explanation: The National party of Nigeria (NPN) won the second republic presidential election. Through the second republic, NPN cooperated and worked with NPP to ensure smooth governance.

Question 32.Question: The relationship between the tiers of government in Nigeria can be described as one of
Question 32.Explanation: The tiers of government in Nigeria are federal, state and local government. The arrangement is hierarchical in order of superiority but each tier has its independent functions that cannot be lawfully performed by the other tiers.

Question 33.Explanation: The 1976 local government reforms introduced a uniform system of local government and made the local government the third –tier of government unlike initially when it was a ministry under the state government.

Question 38.Explanation: Nigeria joined the non-aligned movements in 1964 but was very committed to the movement under Ibrahim Babangida’s military administration. During this period, Nigeria played on active role in the crisis in West African Sub-regional especially Liberia and Sierra Leone.
